context: You know what the real problem with all of this nonsense is?  I saw a documentary where several physicists finally revealed that no matter how fancy a spaceship or fancy a telescope or transportation systems the physical human body flesh cannot withstand space travel and that within a year to year and a half we would be hopelessly crippled and unable to pilot the ship or even be physically able to continue the mission... This is supported by recent visits to the space station where astronauts stayed a year or year and a half upon arrival back at Earth after 18 months in space they were unable to walk nearly blind and physically crippled.... Yet we have all of these Star wars and Star Trek nuts that say well a 13-year mission to planet x would be wonderful if we could travel at light speed and spend 13 years in space which our bodies can't handle

replies.context: Great point! The only space trip I ever thought would be interesting is a trip to the moon. In my mid 50s now and not wealthy so chances are not in my favor, lol.

You need to read beyond the Inquirer.  Yes, vision changes have been documented.  Some may be permanent.  Vision changes also occurred in dive bomber pilots in WWII.  That problem was solved by the G-suit.  Of course, those changes were short term, but the cause was also fluid shift.  Current research also supports a reverse fluid shift compared to what those pilots experienced.  (Black-out are what one usually refers to from negative G, but red-outs are also known.)   The solution may be a as simple as a special space suit, or there may be pharmacologic solutions.  I would favor a mechanical solution to the problem over drugs. 

Nothing from ISS supports the assertion that humans cannot live in micro-gravity for long periods with suitable adaptations.

It was once held as truth that the "physical human body flesh" could not withstand exceeding the speed of sound. I put it to you also a study of occupants of a static, non-rotating (to produce artificial gravity) space station, is not to be considered the final test. Even Skylab had artificial gravity from rotation, with a run by one of the astronauts on the inside walls filmed. 

That said, I agree that the search for another planet doesn't matter at this time, unless we have the ability to actually GO there.

Pluto is and will always be, can‚Äôt change it in my book.
He didn't take Pluto away except in his head. Reject the IAU definition and join the majority of planetary scientists who still consider Pluto--and all dwarf planets--to be a planet.

The trouble is, if you define Pluto as a planet, you must also add hundreds if not thousands of similar bodies in the Kuiper Belt.  It wasn't one scientist who did this.  By definition, a planet must meet three criteria.  1) It must be spherical.  2) It must orbit its star.  3) It must clear its orbit of debris.  Pluto meets the first two but not the third, like many other of its neighbors in deep space.  Pluto is still an amazing celestial body.
Item 3 is quite nebulous. How is the debris field measured? There remains plenty of debris orbiting all planets.
Yes, but there is no debris in their orbit that orbits the sun.
there is plenty of debris in all Solar system planetary orbits, which by definition, orbit the Sun. Just because it is not readily visible doesn't mean it's not there.
You know, I think I'll go with Drs. Thaller, Oluseyi, and Plait have said.  You know, the ones with a Phd in astronomy...

Oh, OK. Ask them and they'll tell you there is debris, just not enough to measure for removal of condition 3. My question was about the condition itself and how "debris" is determined for it.

Your reference to our oceans is irrelevant to this topic. The actual benefit would be that it puts a finer point on the tools used in predicting and pinpointing celestial objects which can't be observed directly by current tools. This in turn would make travel within our solar system less uncertain. This ability will be needed as humans move further and further out into space.

The only thing that makes it irrelevant, TO YOU, is the fact that you can't discuss the merits of spending only a fraction of the money on ocean exploration verses the money that would be spent on travel into the abyss.

replies.context: Nice thought from our childhoods, but unfortunately science says otherwise. Trust the scientific method.
‚ÄúScience‚Äù doesn‚Äôt make definitions. Scientists do. Those are people who often change their minds. Learn the difference. It‚Äôs an important distinction.

Neither science or scientists define or prove anything, nature does. Science exists as a method to discover how nature operates, and the method is for everyone.

The point of the scientific method is so that it can be repeated by anyone under the same circumstances and the same experiment will produce the same results because nature defines the result, not the scientists or science.

Scientists and science does not change its mind. What happens is that when humanity discovers new facets within a given study that the true nature of "nature" unfolds with more information. It's not a matter of mind changing, it's about exploration and discovery.

Definitions are about language, i.e. communication and they are created by the users of language, which are people. ‚ÄúNature‚Äù could not care less about man made definitions. 

You are correct about the nature of ‚Äúproof‚Äù but you are incorrect about the nature of ‚Äúdefinitions.‚Äù

As for ‚Äúscientists,‚Äù they are human beings who make mistakes, lie, are greedy, self-centered, and, yes, they change their minds. Scientists are subject to the same flaws as are all human beings.

As for ‚Äúscience‚Äù changing or not changing its mind, science doesn‚Äôt have a mind to change. ‚ÄúScience‚Äù is not a person. Only persons have minds. Science is a collection of knowledge seeking endeavors, data and measurements, hypotheses an conclusions (which can sometimes be false) and, yes, it is various methods for seeking to increase knowledge. Science is certainly not a person and does not have a mind.

Mike Brown did NOT lead the demotion of Pluto in 2006. He actually had nothing to do with it. It was done by 4% of the International Astronomical Union (IAU), most of whom are not planetary scientists, and was opposed by an equal number of planetary scientists in a formal petition. The debate over Pluto's status and planet definition remains ongoing. Most planetary scientists prefer the geophysical definition over the IAU one. The geophysical definition does not require orbit clearing as a condition for planet status and includes dwarf planets as a subclass of planets. According to this definition, our solar system has a minimum of 13 planets and counting.
Mike Brown is not and never has been a member of the IAU. He did not take part in the vote. However, he is obsessed with the idea that he "killed Pluto" and uses that as a brand to pursue money and fame. He was one of a team of three who discovered the planet Eris in 2005. The other two co-discoverers, David Rabinowitz and Chad Trujillo, reject the IAU planet definition and demotion of Pluto. Rabinowitz even signed the 2006 petition of planetary scientists who opposed it.

Brown deliberately refers to this hypothetical but undiscovered planet as "Planet Nine" to promote himself and his own agenda and pretend the debate over planet definition is over when that is far from the case. It is very sad to see a scientist mislead the public for his own personal gain.
